#> 3                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                The tendency for people to appear more attractive in a group than in isolation.[108]
#> 4                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Attributing more blame to a harm-doer as the outcome becomes more severe or as personal or situational similarity to the victim increases.
#> 5                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Occurs when people claim more responsibility for themselves for the results of a joint action than an outside observer would credit them with.
#> 6                                                                                                                                                                                                                      An exception to the fundamental attribution error, when people view others as having (situational) extrinsic motivations and (dispositional) intrinsic motivations for oneself
#> 7                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            The tendency for people to overestimate the degree to which others agree with them.[109]
#> 8                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           The tendency of people to see their projects and themselves as more singular than they actually are.[110]
#> 9                                                                                      The tendency for people to over-emphasize personality-based explanations for behaviors observed in others while under-emphasizing the role and power of situational influences on the same behavior[84] (see also actor-observer bias, group attribution error, positivity effect, and negativity effect).[85]
#> 10                                                                                                               The biased belief that the characteristics of an individual group member are reflective of the group as a whole or the tendency to assume that group decision outcomes reflect the preferences of group members, even when information is available that clearly suggests otherwise.
#> 11                                                                                                                                                                                                    The tendency for a person's positive or negative traits to "spill over" from one personality area to another in others' perceptions of them (see also physical attractiveness stereotype).[111]
#> 12                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     People perceive their knowledge of their peers to surpass their peers' knowledge of them.[112]
#> 13                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                When people view self-generated preferences as instead being caused by insightful, effective and benevolent agents.
#> 14                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   People overestimate others' ability to know themselves, and they also overestimate their ability to know others.
#> 15                                                                                                                                                                                    Overestimating one's desirable qualities, and underestimating undesirable qualities, relative to other people. (Also known as "Lake Wobegon effect", "better-than-average effect", or "superiority bias".)[113]
#> 16                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  The tendency for people to give preferential treatment to others they perceive to be members of their own groups.
#> 17                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Tendency to judge human action to intentional rather than accidental.[114]
#> 18                                                                                                                                                                                                                     The tendency for people to want to believe that the world is fundamentally just, causing them to rationalize an otherwise inexplicable injustice as deserved by the victim(s).
#> 19                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The tendency for people to ascribe greater or lesser moral standing based on the outcome of an event.
#> 20                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Expecting more egocentric bias in others than in oneself.
#> 21                                                                                                                                                      The belief that we see reality as it really is – objectively and without bias; that the facts are plain for all to see; that rational people will agree with us; and that those who don't are either uninformed, lazy, irrational, or biased.
#> 22                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Individuals see members of their own group as being relatively more varied than members of other groups.[115]
#> 23                                                                                                                                                                Refers to the tendency to attribute cause of an undesirable outcome or wrongdoing by an individual to a moral deficiency or lack of self control rather than taking into account the impact of broader societal determinants .[116]
#> 24                                                                                                                                                           The tendency to claim more responsibility for successes than failures. It may also manifest itself as a tendency for people to evaluate ambiguous information in a way beneficial to their interests (see also group-serving bias).[117]
#> 25                                                                                                         Known as the tendency for group members to spend more time and energy discussing information that all members are already familiar with (i.e., shared information), and less time and energy discussing information that only some members are aware of (i.e., unshared information).[118]
#> 26                                                                                                                                  The tendency to defend and bolster the status quo. Existing social, economic, and political arrangements tend to be preferred, and alternatives disparaged, sometimes even at the expense of individual and collective self-interest. (See also status quo bias.)
#> 27                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       The tendency for people to view themselves as relatively variable in terms of personality, behavior, and mood while viewing others as much more predictable.
#> 28                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Similar to the fundamental attribution error, in this error a person is likely to make an internal attribution to an entire group instead of the individuals within the group.
#> 29                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         A tendency to believe ourselves to be worse than others at tasks which are difficult.[119]

#> [[3]]
#>                                                     Name
#> 1                                     Bizarreness effect
#> 2                        Conservatism or Regressive bias
#> 3                                       Consistency bias
#> 4                                         Context effect
#> 5                                      Cross-race effect
#> 6                                           Cryptomnesia
#> 7                                        Egocentric bias
#> 8                                     Fading affect bias
#> 9                                           False memory
#> 10            Generation effect (Self-generation effect)
#> 11                                         Google effect
#> 12                                          Humor effect
#> 13                                            Lag effect
#> 14                               Leveling and sharpening
#> 15                           Levels-of-processing effect
#> 16                                    List-length effect
#> 17                                 Misinformation effect
#> 18                                       Modality effect
#> 19                            Mood-congruent memory bias
#> 20                                   Next-in-line effect
#> 21                               Part-list cueing effect
#> 22                                         Peak-end rule
#> 23                            Picture superiority effect
#> 24 Positivity effect (Socioemotional selectivity theory)
#> 25                                Serial position effect
#> 26                          Processing difficulty effect
#> 27                                     Reminiscence bump
#> 28                                 Self-relevance effect
#> 29                                      Source confusion
#> 30                                        Spacing effect
#> 31                                      Spotlight effect
#> 32                                    Stereotypical bias
#> 33                                         Suffix effect
#> 34                                        Suggestibility
#> 35                                          Tachypsychia
#> 36                                    Telescoping effect
#> 37                                        Testing effect
#> 38                          Tip of the tongue phenomenon
#> 39                                       Travis Syndrome
#> 40                                       Verbatim effect
#> 41                                   von Restorff effect
#> 42                                      Zeigarnik effect
#>                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Description
#> 1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Bizarre material is better remembered than common material.
#> 2                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   Tendency to remember high values and high likelihoods/probabilities/frequencies as lower than they actually were and low ones as higher than they actually were. Based on the evidence, memories are not extreme enough.[120][121]
#> 3                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       Incorrectly remembering one's past attitudes and behaviour as resembling present attitudes and behaviour.[122]
#> 4                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      That cognition and memory are dependent on context, such that out-of-context memories are more difficult to retrieve than in-context memories (e.g., recall time and accuracy for a work-related memory will be lower at home, and vice versa).
#> 5                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           The tendency for people of one race to have difficulty identifying members of a race other than their own.
#> 6                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            A form of misattribution where a memory is mistaken for imagination, because there is no subjective experience of it being a memory.[123]
#> 7                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Recalling the past in a self-serving manner, e.g., remembering one's exam grades as being better than they were, or remembering a caught fish as bigger than it really was.
#> 8                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            A bias in which the emotion associated with unpleasant memories fades more quickly than the emotion associated with positive events.[124]
#> 9                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 A form of misattribution where imagination is mistaken for a memory.
#> 10                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     That self-generated information is remembered best. For instance, people are better able to recall memories of statements that they have generated than similar statements generated by others.
#> 11                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               The tendency to forget information that can be found readily online by using Internet search engines.
#> 12                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                That humorous items are more easily remembered than non-humorous ones, which might be explained by the distinctiveness of humor, the increased cognitive processing time to understand the humor, or the emotional arousal caused by the humor.[125]
#> 13                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      The phenomenon whereby learning is greater when studying is spread out over time, as opposed to studying the same amount of time in a single session. See also spacing effect.
#> 14                                                                                                                                                                          Memory distortions introduced by the loss of details in a recollection over time, often concurrent with sharpening or selective recollection of certain details that take on exaggerated significance in relation to the details or aspects of the experience lost through leveling. Both biases may be reinforced over time, and by repeated recollection or re-telling of a memory.[126]
#> 15                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             That different methods of encoding information into memory have different levels of effectiveness.[127]
#> 16 A smaller percentage of items are remembered in a longer list, but as the length of the list increases, the absolute number of items remembered increases as well. For example, consider a list of 30 items ("L30") and a list of 100 items ("L100"). An individual may remember 15 items from L30, or 50%, whereas the individual may remember 40 items from L100, or 40%. Although the percent of L30 items remembered (50%) is greater than the percent of L100 (40%), more L100 items (40) are remembered than L30 items (15).[128][further explanation needed]
#> 17                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Memory becoming less accurate because of interference from post-event information.[129]
#> 18                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                That memory recall is higher for the last items of a list when the list items were received via speech than when they were received through writing.
#> 19                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               The improved recall of information congruent with one's current mood.
#> 20                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              When taking turns speaking in a group using a predetermined order (e.g. going clockwise around a room, taking numbers, etc.) people tend to have diminished recall for the words of the person who spoke immediately before them.[130]
#> 21                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  That being shown some items from a list and later retrieving one item causes it to become harder to retrieve the other items.[131]
#> 22                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                That people seem to perceive not the sum of an experience but the average of how it was at its peak (e.g., pleasant or unpleasant) and how it ended.
#> 23                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             The notion that concepts that are learned by viewing pictures are more easily and frequently recalled than are concepts that are learned by viewing their written word form counterparts.[132][133][134][135][136][137]
#> 24                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       That older adults favor positive over negative information in their memories.
#> 25                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              That items near the end of a sequence are the easiest to recall, followed by the items at the beginning of a sequence; items in the middle are the least likely to be remembered.[138]
#> 26                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               That information that takes longer to read and is thought about more (processed with more difficulty) is more easily remembered.[139]
#> 27                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   The recalling of more personal events from adolescence and early adulthood than personal events from other lifetime periods.[140]
#> 28                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 That memories relating to the self are better recalled than similar information relating to others.
#> 29                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               Confusing episodic memories with other information, creating distorted memories.[141]
#> 30                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 That information is better recalled if exposure to it is repeated over a long span of time rather than a short one.
#> 31                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       The tendency to overestimate the amount that other people notice your appearance or behavior.
#> 32                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Memory distorted towards stereotypes (e.g., racial or gender).
#> 33                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               Diminishment of the recency effect because a sound item is appended to the list that the subject is not required to recall.[142][143]
#> 34                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             A form of misattribution where ideas suggested by a questioner are mistaken for memory.
#> 35                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       When time perceived by the individual either lengthens, making events appear to slow down, or contracts.[144]
#> 36                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                The tendency to displace recent events backward in time and remote events forward in time, so that recent events appear more remote, and remote events, more recent.
#> 37                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      The fact that you more easily remember information you have read by rewriting it instead of rereading it.[145]
#> 38                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             When a subject is able to recall parts of an item, or related information, but is frustratingly unable to recall the whole item. This is thought to be an instance of "blocking" where multiple similar memories are being recalled and interfere with each other.[123]
#> 39                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Overestimating the significance of the present.[146] It is related to chronological snobbery with possibly an appeal to novelty logical fallacy being part of the bias.
#> 40                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       That the "gist" of what someone has said is better remembered than the verbatim wording.[147] This is because memories are representations, not exact copies.
#> 41                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 That an item that sticks out is more likely to be remembered than other items.[148]
#> 42                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    That uncompleted or interrupted tasks are remembered better than completed ones.
#>
